@ijuma cherry-picked and fixed (trivial but added two comments in code) your changes and added tests. Hope I hit the right style there :)
\cc @derrickdoo Call for review.
I will wait for the Jenkins build to succeed. I assume you tested the latest update to make sure it still passes after a large number of repeated runs?
@ijuma obv forgot to double check :) but ... just ran another 200+ after your comment and all green :)

@guozhangwang @enothereska @mjsax - found this today when someone on the user list reported strange behaviour with Session Windows. Found it performed terribly with caching enabled, but performed well with it turned off. Eventually narrowed it down to calling `Segments.segments(0, Long.MAX_VALUE)` on each flush. This resulted in about 3 million gets on a ConcurrentHashMap - most of which will miss.

My understanding of the motivation was to distinguish threads across different JVMs within the same machine on the log4j outputs; but I understand your argument now that there are other places than prefix where threadName is used (e.g. outside class `StreamThread`). 

In this case could use just use `clientId + "-StreamThread-" + STREAM_THREAD_ID_SEQUENCE.getAndIncrement()` as the thread name? In this case it works for both when users specify `clientId` or not; the current approach achieves similar result but with a more complex logic.
LGTM. Merged to trunk and cherry-picked to 0.10.2.

@dguy I like your idea, and I think the name of `AdminClient` is fine: for example we can add another method named `getAdmin` in `KafkaClientSupplier` which can then be used in both `KafkaStreams` then passed into each of the thread's `StreamsPartitionAssignor`.

BTW I think we can also piggy-back this with KIP-117 which will introduce an admin client in common package that is can be generally used. Today we have different impls of such client in streams and connect, and that KIP is aimed to condense all these clients.
cc @ijuma, as discussed in #2614.

Some new jenkins failures worth mentioning:

```
org.apache.kafka.streams.integration.JoinIntegrationTest.testLeftKStreamKStream

java.lang.IllegalStateException: No entry found for connection 0
Stacktrace

java.lang.IllegalStateException: No entry found for connection 0
	at org.apache.kafka.clients.ClusterConnectionStates.nodeState(ClusterConnectionStates.java:166)
	at org.apache.kafka.clients.ClusterConnectionStates.connectionState(ClusterConnectionStates.java:156)
	at org.apache.kafka.clients.NetworkClient.connectionFailed(NetworkClient.java:232)
	at org.apache.kafka.clients.consumer.internals.ConsumerNetworkClient.checkDisconnects(ConsumerNetworkClient.java:356)
	at org.apache.kafka.clients.consumer.internals.ConsumerNetworkClient.poll(ConsumerNetworkClient.java:231)
	at org.apache.kafka.clients.consumer.internals.ConsumerNetworkClient.pollNoWakeup(ConsumerNetworkClient.java:259)
	at org.apache.kafka.clients.consumer.internals.AbstractCoordinator$HeartbeatThread.run(AbstractCoordinator.java:911)
```

```
org.apache.kafka.streams.integration.ResetIntegrationTest > testReprocessingFromScratchAfterResetWithIntermediateUserTopic FAILED
    java.lang.IllegalStateException: No entry found for connection 0
```
retest this please

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-pr-jdk8-scala2.12/2035/
Test FAILed (JDK 8 and Scala 2.12).

A few other high level comments.
1. In the EOS message format, it's probably worth considering including the message count in the message format. This has the benefit that the consumer can allocate the right size of the array to store those messages and is also consistent with how we represent an array in other places.

2. About EosLogEntry and OldLogEntry. Perhaps we can name them based on the magic. So, it would be V2LogEntry, V1LogEntry and V0LogEntry.
Wondering what was the overhead mainly from in the current code: I think `poll(0)` which is called most of the time should be mostly no-op, but obviously it was not correct.

@guozhangwang the `No entry found for connection 0` error already has a JIRA: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-4842 however it is not streams-related. The real problem is this: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-4841 and Kafka folks are already looking into it.

@guozhangwang 100MB/s means roughly ~1M 100 byte requests/second. At that speed, everything matters. An extra time.millisecond() drops performance by 20K requests/second. Every single call in that loop is currently done for each single request, which adds up (5% here, 2% there, 10% elsewhere). Even this change is not sufficient for really high perf (e.g., when I run on my laptop and I get 170MB/s baseline and 150MB/s with this change) since there are other things that need optimising (such as addRecords, that will be a separate PR). Basically everything matters :)

Looks like this needs a rebase?

@junrao, about including the message format version as a prefix or suffix. I considered that, but the issue is that more than one version is supported by each class. Unless we want to move away from that, it seems a bit awkward.
cc @ijuma @junrao

@sjmittal Another thought about resolving this deadlock thing, is that we can sort the tasks (i.e. the `newTasks` generated in the `addStreamTasks` and `addStandbyTasks`) to be initialized by their task-ids, so that there will not be a scenario where one thread is grabbing lock for task1 then lock for task2 while the other thread is trying to grab lock for task2 then lock for task1, hence the deadlock.

Even if the deadlock involves more than two threads, having the tasks sorted will make sure that at least one pair of the threads will break the tie with each other and hence there will be no deadlocks. WDYT?

Sounds good to me!
@sharad-develop Can you please update the code according to @guozhangwang suggestion.
@guozhangwang Do you suggest to delay this PR until KIP-117 is done? This might take some time, as the KIP is not even voted yet.
That's a good point: let's not wait for KIP-117 then, and we can do the merge in a separate JIRA after that is done.

Sounds good to me. I did create a JIRA for this: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-4857

@sharad-develop Can you follow up with this PR and address the comments. Thanks.

@guozhangwang To some extent it makes sense when we talk in 2 threads scenario. However I am not able to visualize when there are more than 2 threads and tasks of thread 1 are moved to different threads and if we can have some three way deadlock.
